title: TIL calling someone delusional leads to perm-ban!
body:
Situation - I was in a game with 3 of my friends and 1 random. 
The random guy was flaming me the entire game, and apparently me calling him delusional is considered toxic enough to get me banned!
(The monkey fuck part wasnt even adressed at this guy, it was addressed to one of my friends playing the game)

replies.body: This alone deserves 10 games chat restrict. But you already had 14 dayd ban. So yeah it clearly says that its your final warning and the next ban is gonna be pernament. You choosed to keep going and insult people. So sorry for your account and good luck with your new one :)

Thanks, I guess the ban system is what irritates me the most about this tbh.

Someone could say much worse things on their first warning and receive a slap on the wrist, but when you're on thin ice something that isnt nearly as bad can get you permd. 

Even if people were to go through the natural progression by saying things (such as this) , people that spam the N word (hard r), R word, etc can still get a slap on the wrist if its theior first warning

Actually things like racist language, wishing death on others and gameplay-related offenses violate the zero-tolerance policy and thus get a 14-day ban as the first punishment since ideally one shouldn't need a warning to know not to behave like that. That aside I understand that in your case you lost patience with that players behavior, and that's understandable. That said, if you had muted them and not engaged with them then chances are you wouldn't have been punished, which I realize is easier said than done but still though. Under normal circumstances you would only get a chat restriction for this log (assuming that's all that was said), but because you already had those plus a 2-week ban you were given a permaban as the next available punishment.

As for the escalation system yes I know it can feel frustrating to get permaed over something that would normally only get a slap on the wrist, however, you have to understand that players can't keep getting infinite chances, and Riot has decided that a person who still is acting up after a 14-day ban with no noticeable improvements despite knowing they're on thin ice should be permabanned since it's highly unlikely that additional chances will change anything.

>Actually things like racist language, wishing death on others and gameplay-related offenses violate the zero-tolerance policy and thus get a 14-day ban as the first punishment since ideally one shouldn't need a warning to know not to behave like that.

Don't mean to be a party pooper, but it's actually not like this. I have been banned for spamming the K acronym 24 times with copy->paste just to flood the chat, so I wouldn't see what the person flaming me was typing. Was it okay? Nope, definitely not. Did it deserve an instant two week ban? Maybe, I'd take other things into consideration first. Is it always like this? Nope, it is not. After I got banned, my friends laughed their asses off, because it was my first ever punishment since 2011, when I created my account. Later that day they tried recreating said result - getting a 14-day vacation after just one game, deliberately spamming stuff like K acronym, racial slurs, antisemitic stuff, etc. What did he get for that? A 10 game chat restriction. And the game after that, when he did the same thing again? A 25 game chat restriction.

Now would you mind telling me how a low level account gets a slap on the wrist, when it could potentially be a toxic player who got permabanned and decided to come back just to ruin the experience more, meanwhile a player who didn't really do anything wrong for 8 years straight gets the harsh one for a single meltdown? And it's literally a single one game.

Don't get me wrong tho, I'm over that ban already, have somewhat reformed by disabling the chat altogether and not even responding in lobby to questions if I can first pick someone their champ - they could report it and chat logs are the only evidence, so you gotta watch out.

Let's have you understand the behavioral system a bit more. Think of it like a health bar (or tension meter) in music games. When you hit the note at an off beat,  your tension meter  increases. When you completely miss a note, the meter increases by alot. When you hit the note at good timings, it reduces the meter. 

Riot's behavior system works the same way, as in we all have a toxicity meter attached to our accounts. When players are mildly toxic, it goes up a tad. When people use hate speech, it pretty much fills up the meter. of course, clean games reduce the meter. 

It is possible for playerA to get punished and playerB not to, even though playerB was waaayyyyy more toxic . Let's say playerA started the game with the toxicity meter at 95% and playerB's at 35%. Ingame, playerB said some pretty nasty shit and playerA responds with some shit as well. After the game, playerA gains 10% toxicity and playerB gains 50%. Now playerA is at 105% toxicity and gets punished, whereas playerB is at 85%, and not punished in that specific game, even though playerB was found to be 5x more toxic than playerA in that game.
that actually makes a lot of sense, good explanation! Thanks

And thats the thing after get their first warning they can choose to change or keep breaking the rules. Sometimes 1 warning is enough for a person to change. In your case you got 3 slaps on the wrist but you didnt changed so riot decided to give you a punch. Again no hard feelings bit thats how it works for everyone.

If you were to say that you didn't agree that you were adequately warned for the trigger words of "delusional" and "money fuck", you have a valid, but worthless, argument. It's valid because nobody can take that from you if it's honest, and is an objective reason you should not be banned. It's worthless because it won't get your ban lifted**.**

Emphasis on the **.**

It appears, however, you simply disagreed with Riot regarding the use of these words, and that is not a valid argument. And you're 100% free to disagree, and get as many people as you want to find to share that opinion. There are a bunch. I am one of them. I'm not taking high ground here, but I abide by the rules anyway. 

In honesty, I'm claiming it's the high ground to disagree with these rules, but unless it's your intent to discuss that, that doesn't seem to be the purpose of this thread.

So in your personal opinion, do you personally think that calling a playing delusional (when they are by definition..) makes me part of the .0006% that is toxic enough to receive a perm-ban?

At what point is calling someone dumb, or to shut up going to be toxic and can potentially banned?

It's demeaning. It may be accurate, but it's still personally offensive. So it's an offense to the rules. Ignore the .0006% part, that's propaganda to promote the banning system's effectiveness. It's not an outright lie, but it is a misrepresentation of the truth.

You are not particularly toxic. If you regularly talk like that, I might personally put you at around the bottom 35-ish percent in terms of your use of chat. In the full spectrum of toxicity, if your play is good - that is, you don't noticeably tilt in the way you control your champion, you'd be in the top half.

Rest assured, I am trying to fight for players like you, but it is a losing battle because I don't have a PhD and the SJWs are in waxing phase.

I'm just upset because the guy was flaming me the entire game lol and I get perm'd for that but he gets to flame me and continue playing. 

Do you think theres a point in time that I would be able to appeal this ban?

There's a bunch to it that I'm frankly not inclined to type here because the rules are pretty well worded as is.

I'll restate that telling someone they're delusional is demeaning, and *anything* that is demeaning is against the rules. "GG EZ" is against the rules, but few are punished for it because of how the reporting system works. Consistent reports are a key factor, and most people do not report for "GG EZ", but in your case, you're more clearly being demeaning and thus more players have reported you.

When the current banning system is reformed, you should reappeal. Which might not happen. You'd have to ask the right questions for me to continue. (angry fist waving at moderator)

Thing is only 1 person could have reported me since the 3 others were friends in that game lol, but I see what you're saying. 

Pretty much it depends on the rioter, and what they consider demeaning?

ALso, is the current banning system getting reformed?

It's the ban-bot. A dictionary-based banning program. It is, basically, a 'learning' program that identifies trigger words with correlation to reports. The rioters will not disagree with the bot. Years ago, this system was designed around behavior at the time. It was well designed and accurate. However, over time, the bot has broadly accepted any toxicity - no matter how slight - as universally BAD, with varying tiers of BAD. As players realized that they can contribute to banning others based on their chat, they've contributed to the bot accepting even minor degradation as punishable, particularly when the player in question repeatedly uses the same phrases and key words. In other words, the excessive reports, effortlessly processed by the bot, have compiled a blatantly pandering list of triggers. So, as stated, the rioter's opinion doesn't really matter- they must agree with the bot, if the bot says it was bad mouthing. All the rioter needs to do is to find some of those keywords the program identified and show it to you, then hands off, "too bad so sad Charlie."

They will help if you can prove someone stole your account or some other extenuating circumstance.

The system is not being reformed, but Riot MAY be aware- or MAYBE becoming aware- that their current system is no longer as effective as it used to be. More direct questions required to continue.

Oh, so pretty much over time because of people that report for any little thing the bot is no longer triggered from severely toxic players, rather by any slight form of toxicity ?

It is not that effective anymore because rioters have no say in what is considered bannable; they HAVE to ban becasue the bot said so?

I'll hint to the large number of bots swarming vs AI games. This effectively means that banning is practically ineffective to those that work around it. Without any real punishment to these players, they're realistically free to be as toxic as they want. Sucks for those of us with accounts that we paid for or otherwise care about, like you and I- although the majority of players do not get punished. Do not let that discourage you, however. The majority is never a good reason for anything unless in a very bad situation.

the bot is fairly accurate

The program, supposedly, has a 100% accuracy with regard to identifying toxic behavior. There's only one way this is possible: without regard to context. Riot explicitly states in the ToS that context does not matter. Thus- the human side does not matter- if somebody regularly responds to toxicity with significant enough consistency, the program identifies the player as a problem. This is the greatest flaw of the system, it does not care why (or for what purpose) you're condescending or otherwise toxic. In reality, WITH REGARD TO CONTEXT, the system is not 100% accurate, because I can objectively argue why you specifically (among many others) should not be banned for such behavior, referencing discussions among the intelligent community concerned with online behavior. *Regardless of how relevant my argument is, if it isn't inherently wrong, the program is not 100% accurate.* My argument also has to deal with the system's affect on players. That argument is worthless, however, in likeness to my first response to you. Because I don't have a PhD. Though if I work on this enough it might get me one... in my dreams. A Ted Talk at best. Still dreaming.

The reason I explain that is, again, the system is hailed as 100% accurate, the replacement for Tribunal. There is only one reason they would claim it is. I'll point out that someone is getting paid for this program's success and someone else wants it to be toted as a success. The Tribunal failed at that. Keep in mind that League has a very negative reputation in the real world for its toxicity, but among the elite, they've managed to project League as an example of how companies should handle toxicity, with this program at the tip. The intelligent community will not read the ToS and don't know that the system has no regard to the human side of the veil of toxicity- and tragically, that community is all about the human side of things. That's really why they're all there in the first place. It's just a few who have the clout, import, and interest in looking good that are doing this. It's ironic that Riot's symbol represents clout.

That's not to say Riot is evil. Hell naw! They've got some good things going and have helped. Even the very program in question is ... WAS ... an advancement for player behavior. **A summarized answer to your first question** is that they are employees in an organization in which they answer to the people who in some way are paid for having an excellent behavior system. No overrides of the bot's judgement equals 100% accuracy (excluding extreme situations the bot could not measure). You seem to have already been aware of this to some degree. Emphasis *"Too bad, so sad."* I would call you a sacrifice in the name of this 'excellent behavior program'. The punishments must flow, and none are exceptions in the bot's eyes. For cryin' out loud, they changed the ToS so that the bot's judgement is always 'right'!

For what it's worth, I think I could make a better system- with help. Sorry it's not here yet.
